docs.lead_paragraph: Men who exercise regularly and strenuously in their early years are less likely to develop Parkinson's disease when they are older, a new study suggests. The health histories of 48,000 men indicated that those who had been the most active had half the risk of Parkinson's disease as those who had been the least active, the lead author of the work, Dr. Honglei Chen of the Harvard School of Public Health reported in the journal Neurology. While the association between exercise and the occurrence of Parkinson's appeared strong, the explanation is uncertain.
docs.abstract: Dr Honglei Chen of Harvard School of Public Health leads study that shows men have reduced risk of developing Parkinson's disease later in life, if they exercised vigorously and regularly when they were younger; study is published in journal Neurology (S)
docs.snippet: Men who exercise regularly and strenuously in their early years are less likely to develop Parkinson's disease when they are older, a new study suggests.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Plastic wrap in a microwave can expose food to dioxins. THE FACTS -- A widely circulated e-mail message has caused fears that heating plastics in the microwave can contaminate food with dioxins, a group of carcinogens. Experts say there is little truth to this: dioxins almost never turn up in commercial plastics.
docs.abstract: Research shows that using plastic wrap and food containers in microwave will not expose person to dioxins; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: THE CLAIM -- Plastic wrap in a microwave can expose food to dioxins.    THE FACTS -- A widely circulated e-mail message has caused fears that heating plastics in the microwave can contaminate food with dioxins, a group of carcinogens. Experts say...

docs.lead_paragraph: Why soccer would be a risk for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a mystery. But a new study has found that Italian professional soccer players get the disease at a rate nearly six times as great as the general population.

headline.main: An A.L.S. Puzzle On the Soccer Field

docs.abstract: Prof Adriano Chio of University of Turin neuroscience department leads research that finds Italian professional soccer players have died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis at rate almost 12 times greater than general population; reason for higher risk of getting ALS is unclear, but research suggests several possible explanations including environmental factors, physical demands of game and possible drug use; research is published in journal Brain (M)
docs.snippet: A new study has found that Italian professional soccer players get the rare disease at a rate nearly six times as great as the general population.

docs.lead_paragraph: For the past 25 years, Dr. Richard B. Gartner, a faculty member at the William Alanson White Institute in Manhattan, has been developing therapies and treating men who suffered sexual abuse during childhood. With a new book about to be released by John Wiley & Sons, ''Beyond Betrayal: Taking Charge of Your Life After Boyhood Sexual Abuse,'' Dr. Gartner, 58, sat in a Chelsea kitchen on a recent Saturday morning and spoke about the experiences that drew him to this work.

headline.main: Beyond the Bounds of Betrayal: Men Cope With Being the Victims

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Richard B Gartner, William Alanson White Institute faculty member and author of book Beyond Betrayal: Taking Charge of Your Life After Boyhood Sexual Abuse; Gartner has spent past 25 years leading efforts to help men heal from abuse; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For the past 25 years, Dr. Richard B. Gartner has been developing therapies and treating men who suffered sexual abuse during childhood.

docs.lead_paragraph: Resilience. Call it what you will -- the ability to weather stresses large and small, to bounce back from trauma and get on with life, to learn from negative experiences and translate them into positive ones, to muster the strength and confidence to change directions when a chosen path becomes blocked or nonproductive. Or you can sum it up as actualization of A.A.'s serenity prayer: ''Grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change, the courage to change the things I can and the wisdom to know the difference.''

headline.main: Get a Grip: Set Your Sights Above Adversity

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses resilient individuals and how trait can be nurtured and developed; Drs Robert Brooks of Harvard University and Sam Goldstein of University of Utah, who have co-authored book The Power of Resilience, assert that people who do not develop ability to handle adversity often waste time and energy on matters they cannot control rather than attack problems head on and learn from them; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Resilience isn't just inborn: it can, and should, be learned.

docs.lead_paragraph: A team of Dutch scientists is trying to solve the mystery of personality. Why are some individuals shy while others are bold, for example? What roles do genes and environment play in shaping personalities? And most mysterious of all, how did they evolve? The scientists are carrying out an ambitious series of experiments to answer these questions. They are studying thousands of individuals, observing how they interact with others, comparing their personalities to their descendants' and analyzing their DNA.

headline.main: Looking for Personality in Animals, of All People

docs.abstract: Researchers explore role of genetics and environment on development of both animal and human personalities; Dr Piet Drent of Netherlands Institute of Ecology leads study that shows individual birds behave in consistently different ways and therefore have distinct personalities; holds that natural selection does not narrow range of personalities in animals because so many factors can impact what personality traits are favorable at given time; research is published in Neuroscience and Biobehavioral Reviews; evolution of human personality discussed; photos; chart (L)
docs.snippet: A team of scientists is trying to solve the mystery of personality. What may come as a surprise is that their subjects have feathers.

docs.lead_paragraph: She was an internist by training, but privately I always called her the eye doctor. Ask her about any of her patients, and the answer would come back starting with ''I.'' How was Mr. Jones? ''I got him to start taking his insulin, and I'm working on his cholesterol.''

headline.main: Report Cards for Doctors? Grades Are Likely to Be A, B, C ... and I

docs.snippet: Precise rankings lie just over the horizon, with doctors publicly graded and paid by the good results they achieve.

docs.lead_paragraph: In investigating the case of a 46-year-old New York City man with a rare and possibly virulent strain of H.I.V., public health officials are relying on the classic method of sexual-contact tracing, cutting edge laboratory tests -- and luck. First, epidemiologists, promising confidentiality, must depend on the man's cooperation in naming his sexual partners so that they can track down and interview each one. Depending on what they learn from those who agree to cooperate, the medical detectives may repeat the process with each infected partner.

headline.main: The Challenge of Tracing a Rare H.I.V. Strain

docs.abstract: Report by Dr Thomas R Frieden, New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene commissioner, on 46-year-old New York City man with rare and potentially serious strain of HIV has set off investigation into background of infection; challenges facing investigators discussed; many AIDS experts are concerned new and more virulent strain of HIV could mean significant rise in AIDS epidemic (M)
docs.snippet: In investigating the case of a rare strain of H.I.V., public health officials are relying on classic methods  and luck.

docs.lead_paragraph: People who lose their hearing as they grow older should not be so quick to blame their ears. The problem may be with their brains. Researchers say that in many cases, the ears of hearing-impaired people are just fine. But when the signals reach their aging brains, things begin to go wrong. The findings were presented at a recent conference of the Association for Research in Otolaryngology, where researchers were trying to home in on exactly what is happening in the brain in these cases.

headline.main: Blame the Brain for Hearing Loss

docs.abstract: Dr Robert D Frisina of University of Rochester Medical Center leads study that suggests hearing loss in elderly could be caused by changes in brain's ability to process sensory information, not actual hearing loss; findings were presented at Assn for Research in Otolaryngology conference; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People who lose their hearing as they grow older should not be so quick to blame their ears. The problem may be with their brains.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors have known for years that giving patients a quick dose of antibiotics shortly before the first surgical incision is made will reduce the risk of infection. But a new study that looked at more than 2,900 hospitals has found that this is done only about half the time. The study, led by Dr. Dale W. Bratzler of the Oklahoma Foundation for Medical Quality, appears in the current Archives of Surgery.

headline.main: A Quick Fix for Safer Surgery

docs.abstract: Dr Dale W Bratzler of Oklahoma Foundation for Medical Quality leads study on use of antibiotics prior to surgery to reduce risk of infection; research, which is published in Archives of Surgery, shows that although preoperative antibiotics have proven benefits they are not routinely given before surgery; antibiotics were found to be administered correctly for around 55 percent of all surgeries; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study says that a quick dose of antibiotics that can reduce the risk of infection after the first surgical incision is only given about half the time.
